Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: IoT Smart Water Management System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide a simple to use "smoke alarm" for water appliances coupled with a level of insight into water consumption and failures that has never existed before. What was once a reliance on water meter data for the sum of all appliances is now a detailed understanding for each individual water fixture. This unprecedented access to water usage data at an individual appliance level will provide the opportunity for increased data analytics research, predictive analytics for failure modes and maintenance scheduling, and better understanding of human consumption habits to identify and solve problems that allow organizations to meet aggressive sustainability goals. Only recently has there been an ability for hospitals to aggregate their medical information to aid research efforts to treat and cure chronic diseases and illnesses. Mobius is looking to do the same for any building owner for water, as the growing concern to continued, reasonable costing fresh water becomes even greater.

The proposed project will provide the opportunity for the development of an IoT Smart Water Management System (SWMS). It will use artificial intelligence and machine learning to both identify leaks so they can be corrected before wasting precious water and energy, and provide predictive analytics for actionable insights. This will significantly improve water appliance maintenance and prevent costly water damage to properties. Further, at a macro level, it provides municipality level insight for maintenance and crisis management. The vision is to easily install these SWMS devices into any existing water fixture. It will take less than 60 seconds to install and connect to the Internet. The design goal is to be cost-effective from the start. The SWMS provides an affordable and easy way to adopt data driven decision making into current operations. The critical objectives set forth in this proposal are centered on achieving a simple "smoke alarm" like warning of a fault coupled with a robust analytics platform. Finally, these will be designed as highly durable IoT devices that require little or no maintenance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Have you ever stayed in an apartment or hotel that had a leak? Unfortunately, about half of us have had that experience in the last decade. The problem is that most water leaks creep up so slowly that, in a commercial building, owners often do not notice the problem until significant amounts of water have been wasted and damage is done. Now imagine a building smart enough to tell you exactly how water is being used, where its being wasted, or how soon you need to check a fixture or consider preemptive repairs. The feasibility of a solution is enabled by Mobius Labs with support from the National Science Foundation.

While many interesting options to detect leaks are available today, we learned from our customer interviews that most are not 'fit for purpose' in the commercial building and residential rental environments, where water and sewer costs may be one of the fastest-growing uncontrolled expenses. We have designed and tested the feasibility of an IoT solution that installs and is working in less than two minutes. Finally, the IoT device detected and reported leaks, and the software demonstrated the feasibility of generating valuable data analytics.

Our major accomplishments were aligned with our primary objectives and evolved with the support of our collaborators.  The following are highlights for the accomplishments enabled by the grant.

We selected a water fixture to start with based on customer feedback. From our NSF I-Corps Site experience, we had a sense that it was going to be the toilet. We learned this is the most ignored leak. This hypothesis was validated during the Beat the Odds process and tested successfully with an MVP. We demonstrated the feasibility of a device operable in this environment. We then added MVP software to provide the different customer archetypes with the appropriate information. This software iterated quickly as we learned the level of information the different archetypes valued.

We developed an alert and alarm communications strategy that respected what we learned about the different customer archetypes. For example, we learned operators care about water and sewer costs but don’t know how to effectively manage them and want zero risk on customer experience, the internet service provider wants the smallest possible data footprint, and property managers want to avoid these losses but want to make sure the solution doesn’t make their jobs harder with additional things to check and respond to. We designed, iterated and tested many methods with several archetypes. We achieved this goal and have a beta version of alarm and alert options for multiple customer archetypes. These were tested in several properties.

The initial devices are battery powered. We learned this was acceptable as several battery powered items are used in this space already. We matched our battery life goal to theirs. We developed an architecture that enabled us to demonstrate battery life of 18 months. This was achieved in the lab and demonstrated with accelerated life testing.

We learned that a weakness of many components in the water system in this space fail due to oxidation and corrosion. We developed a cost effective and corrosion resistant design that lasts at least 18 months.

In closing, it is generally accepted that in many parts of the U.S., the production, delivery and treatment of clean water is increasingly expensive, and that water is an increasingly scarce resource. A solution is needed to help improve efficient use of our water. The Phase I objectives for demonstrating the feasibility of this IoT technology for water conservation and efficiency were met or exceeded. This was accomplished with NSF support while maintaining a simple, inexpensive technology platform.
